awd_titl_txt: RUI: The molecular basis of a genetically accommodated larval color polyphenism
awd_abstract_narration:
Phenotypic plasticity refers to the ability of an organism to generate distinct morphological, behavioral or metabolic changes in response to environmental changes. Laboratory and theoretical research has shown that phenotypic plasticity may play an important role in shaping the evolutionary trajectory of species, although the underlying mechanism remains poorly understood. This project will lead to a better understanding of the molecular and physiological basis of phenotypic plasticity by comparing two strains of caterpillars that differ in their response to temperature: one strain remains black at all temperatures and another turns green at higher temperatures. Black caterpillars have lower levels of juvenile hormone than green caterpillars, and the project will elucidate the regulation of this important hormone that controls insect growth and development. Determining the molecular and physiological basis of phenotypic plasticity has important implications for our understanding of environmentally-induced diseases, generation of novel traits, and species conservation. Much of the proposed study will involve female undergraduate researchers from Wellesley College who will be exposed to research in integrative biology. These students will be encouraged to present at national meetings and publish their contribution in peer-reviewed journals. The award will support inquiry-based learning in the classroom, and will also expose undergraduate and high school students from underrepresented groups to scientific research.

The specific goal of the proposed study is to determine the genetic mechanism underlying the evolution of an artificially selected polyphenism. In this study, the transcriptomes of the neuroendocrine complex in a monophenic strain of the tobacco hornworm, Manduca sexta, and the polyphenic strain will be compared, as these strains differ in the temperature sensitivity of juvenile hormone production. Once candidate temperature-sensitive genes are identified, the flour beetle Tribolium castaneum and RNA interference techniques will be used to functionally characterize these genes. The project will uncover the genetic basis of genetic accommodation and identify the molecular nature of hidden genetic variation, which remains poorly understood. It will lead to a mechanistic understanding of genotype-phenotype-environment interactions and advance understanding of molecular and physiological control of juvenile hormone production. Determining the molecular nature of genetic accommodation and phenotypic plasticity has implications for our understanding of evolution. The findings may also help identify novel regulators of juvenile hormone that could serve as potential targets for pest management. By involving high school and college students in the research and integrating teaching with research, the project also contributes to training the next generation of scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit 

Genetic accommodation is an evolutionary process by which an environmentally induced novel phenotype is selected for and becomes fixed or evolves into a polyphenism. How this process occurs at the molecular level remains poorly understood. In this project, two strains of the tobacco hornworm, Manduca sexta, were evolved through the process of genetic accommodation: one strain was polyphenic and was green at higher temperatures and black at lower temperatures, while the other strain was monophenic and remained black at all temperatures. Using RNA sequencing of tissues, differentially expressed genes were identified in these artificially selected polyphenic and monophenic strains. Specifically, we found that selection for polyphenism led to the evolution of temperature sensitive juvenile hormone (JH) titers and this was correlated with changes in several JH biosynthesis genes as well as changes in JH degradation. We also identified distinct expression of histone modifier genes. In addition, we found that genetic assimilation of the monophenic strain was correlated with changes in DNA methylation. To further study the genes identified in the RNA-seq screen, we explored the potential role of histone modifier genes using the milkweed bug, Oncopeltus fasciatus, and found the Polycomb group proteins are involved in maintaining phenotypic robustness in this species. Thus, epigenetic regulators appear to play an important role in phenotypic plasticity and robustness. We also identified chronologically inappropriate morphogenesis (chinmo) as one of the genes that is upregulated in response to heat shock. We found that although Chinmo is upregulated by JH, it is not dependent on the JH signaling pathway. Together, the findings demonstrate that genetic accommodation proceeds through changes involving a complex interaction of endocrine and epigenetic regulators. Our findings have broader implications for understanding how populations might evolve under extreme environmental conditions.

 

Broader Impacts  

This funding supported training of a total of 37 undergraduate students in research. The funding allowed us to participate in Wellesley’s First-Year Student Research Apprenticeship Program, which allows first-year students with limited background in research to join a lab, and the Sophomore Early Research Program (SERP), which allows sophomore students with limited research experience to partake in paid research experience. A number of these students presented their work at the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology meetings and the International Insect Hormone Workshop. Several students also co-authored manuscripts in peer-reviewed journals. Finally, the funding enabled students to conduct a semester long independent research project in the classroom where students gained experience in research design and molecular biology. This opportunity provided independent research experiences to nearly 60 undergraduate juniors and seniors.
